One-line Summary: VP Reliability shared offshore spares crisis story from 2023 Hebron platform shutdown
Last Incident Story: Hydraulic actuator failure on subsea BOP required class-approved replacement. Original OEM (Cameron) discontinued the model. Took 14 days to source alternative + get Lloyd's approval.
Workaround Used: Temporary manual override rigged by maintenance crew (not class-approved, only used for 48hrs until temporary solution arrived). Final solution: sourced used actuator from Norway rig being decommissioned.
Tools Used Today: Email, Excel spreadsheets for parts tracking, SAP (but doesn't track class approvals), phone calls to brokers
Blockers: Class society approval process (Lloyd's Register required 3D scan + material certs for substitute part), OEM obsolescence (Cameron discontinued product line in 2019), Offshore logistics (helicopter charter cost $45k for urgent part delivery)
Veto Owner (Role): Head of HSE (veto on non-class-approved workarounds)
Metrics Mentioned: 14-day production shutdown = $8.4M revenue loss, Helicopter charter = $45K, Broker premium = 300% markup on used part
Pilot Use Case: Offshore platform - pre-approved substitute parts catalog with embedded class approvals + digital material certificates
Next Step: Send pilot proposal focused on subsea BOP parts catalog
Notes: STRONG CHAMPION - expressed frustration with current process 8 times in 45min call. Willing to sponsor 60-day pilot on one platform.

Asset Context: QA manager shared certification bottleneck for BP offshore repairs
Trigger Event: Cracked flange on high-pressure gas line required emergency weld repair. Welder certification from Norway not recognized by Canadian authorities (TC).
Delay (hours): Flange crack on HP gas line
Tools Used Today: Flew Canadian-certified welder from Alberta (24hr mobilization). Meanwhile, platform ran at 60% capacity with gas flow restricted.
Blockers: PDF folders on shared drive for welder certs, Email, Phone calls to regulatory authorities
Pain Owner (Role): Welder certification reciprocity (Norwegian vs Canadian standards), Regulatory approval delays (Transport Canada took 48hrs to review Norwegian certs and still rejected), Skills availability (only 3 welders in Canada certified for this specific pressure rating)
Budget Owner (Role): Operations Manager (signed off on 60% capacity workaround)
Metrics Mentioned: N/A - repair cost covered under insurance
Pilot Candidate (Y/N): 72 hours partial shutdown = $2.1M revenue loss, Emergency welder mobilization = $18K, Re-certification of welder onsite = $5K
Linked Hypotheses: Not a good fit - certification reciprocity is regulatory issue, not parts issue
column30: Pain is real but outside our scope. Provided referral to certification consultant.

One-line Summary: Chief Engineer described configuration nightmare on AOPS frigate program
Last Incident Story: Valve supplier (Belimo) discontinued a specific actuator model mid-build. Engineering needed to qualify substitute, but design change required approval from RCN, LR (class), and ITAR review (US-origin components).
Workaround Used: Stockpiled 200 units of old actuator model from European distributor before it was fully discontinued (cost premium: 400%). This 'bought time' for 60 days while substitute qualification happened.
Tools Used Today: Excel (BOM tracking), Siemens Teamcenter (PLM), Email, SharePoint (document repository)
Blockers: Design change approval process (RCN Engineering Authority took 45 days to approve substitute), ITAR compliance (substitute had US-origin electronics requiring export license amendment), Supplier obsolescence (Belimo gave 90-day notice, but procurement didn't flag it until 30 days left)
Veto Owner (Role): Director of Quality (veto on non-qualified parts)
Metrics Mentioned: 60-day delay to AOPS-2 build = estimated $12M program delay cost, Stockpile premium = $320K, Engineering re-qualification NRE = $85K
Pilot Use Case: Naval shipbuilding - real-time obsolescence monitoring + pre-qualified substitute database with embedded ITAR/class approvals
Next Step: Send detailed pilot proposal - 90-day trial on AOPS-3 build
Notes: CHAMPION + EXECUTIVE SPONSOR POSSIBILITY. Jennifer mentioned CFO is 'desperate' for digital tools to reduce program delays. Offered to intro us to CFO and VP Procurement.

Asset Context: Maintenance manager shared remote mine parts logistics nightmare
Trigger Event: Bearing failure on SAG mill required replacement. Nearest spare was in warehouse in Vancouver (8-hour truck drive). Truck broke down en route, adding 14 hours. Mill was down for 38 hours total.
Tools Used Today: Ran secondary ball mill at 120% capacity (manufacturer warns against >110%). Caused premature wear, but kept some production going. Output was 60% of normal.
Blockers: Excel, Maximo (CMMS), WhatsApp (field crew communication), Satellite phone
Pain Owner (Role): Remote logistics (truck breakdown added 14hrs), Spare parts inventory (only one spare in system, no redundancy), Supplier lead time (new bearing from SKF = 6 weeks from Sweden)
Budget Owner (Role): Mine General Manager (approved 120% ball mill operation)
Pilot Candidate (Y/N): 38-hour mill downtime = $1.9M revenue loss, Premature ball mill wear = estimated $200K in accelerated replacement, Emergency truck charter = $8K
Linked Hypotheses: Not immediately applicable - 3D printing can't replace large bearings (yet). But expressed interest in smaller wear parts (liners, chute plates).
Next Action Date: Follow up re: smaller wear parts opportunity
column30: Bearing case not a fit, but mine has 200+ smaller parts (crusher liners, conveyor components) that could be 3D printed onsite. Asked for parts list.

One-line Summary: Discovery call - Saudi Aramco asset integrity
Fleet maintenance across Transocean global rig fleet

Asset Context: Awaiting response - container fleet parts provisioning

One-line Summary: Materials director shared CVN-80 program material traceability challenges
Last Incident Story: Fastener supplier (Alcoa Fastening Systems) discontinued a specific bolt grade mid-program. Navy Nuclear Propulsion Program (NR) requires material traceability to heat lot. Substitute bolt from different supplier required full re-qualification including radiation testing.
Workaround Used: Stockpiled 50,000 units of original bolt (cost: $1.2M) to cover build. Simultaneously started 90-day qualification of substitute (cost: $450K including radiation testing at Naval Reactors facility).
Tools Used Today: Oracle PLM, Excel (material cert tracking), SharePoint, Physical file cabinets (NR requires paper backups)
Blockers: Nuclear qualification process (NR testing takes 90 days minimum), Material traceability (every bolt must trace to heat lot + radiation test cert), Supplier obsolescence (Alcoa gave 6-month notice but material engineering didn't see it until 2 months left)
Veto Owner (Role): NR Quality Assurance (absolute veto on nuclear components)
Metrics Mentioned: 90-day program delay = estimated $45M (carrier program runs $500K/day in overhead), Stockpile cost = $1.2M, Re-qualification NRE = $450K
Pilot Use Case: Naval nuclear program - digital material traceability + obsolescence early-warning + pre-qualified substitute database
Next Step: Send executive pilot proposal - CVN-81 program application
Notes: EXECUTIVE-LEVEL CHAMPION. William said 'If you can solve this, I will personally walk you into the CNO's office.' Mentioned program delays due to material issues cost Navy $200M+ annually across all programs.

One-line Summary: Digital operations lead shared BHP remote mine digital twin vision
Last Incident Story: Conveyor idler bearing failure caused 6-hour production stoppage. Site maintenance had spare bearing, but it was wrong size (data entry error in Maximo 2 years ago). Correct bearing was 14-hour truck drive from Adelaide.
Trigger Event: Conveyor bearing failure - wrong spare in inventory
Workaround Used: Fabricated temporary bushing onsite using lathe. Ran conveyor at 70% speed for 18 hours until correct bearing arrived. metallurgy team confirmed bushing was safe for 24hr operation.
Tools Used Today: Maximo (CMMS), SAP, Excel, Slack (crew communication), Dataiku (trying to build digital twin but struggling with data quality)
Blockers: Inventory data accuracy (Maximo had wrong part number - error from 2018), Remote logistics (14hr truck drive), Supplier consolidation (BHP trying to standardize on fewer bearing SKUs but engineering hasn't approved substitutes yet)
Budget Owner (Role): VP Operations - Olympic Dam (approved digital twin budget)
Metrics Mentioned: 20-hour partial production loss = $800K revenue, Emergency truck charter = $12K, Engineering time for bushing design = $8K
Pilot Use Case: Remote mining - digital twin for predictive maintenance + on-demand AM for wearing parts (bearings, bushings, idlers) + real-time spare parts catalog
Next Step: Send pilot proposal - 6-month trial at Olympic Dam (focus on conveyors + crushers)
Notes: STRONG CHAMPION + BUDGET AUTHORITY. Emma has $5M digital innovation budget for 2026. Mentioned 'board is pushing for Industry 4.0 showcase' and Olympic Dam is the flagship site. Willing to co-fund pilot 50/50.
